document_title: Ureteral stones: Causes, signs and treatments
subsection_content:
You can reduce your risk of ureteral stones by:
Add enough water to the body: For patients with a history of kidney stones, you should eliminate about 2.5 liters of urine per day. Light yellow and clear urine is a sign that the body is sufficiently hydrated.; Limit the addition of foods high in calcium oxalate such as cheese, milk, thick tea, radishes, okra.; Limit intake of salt and animal protein: In your daily meals, you should reduce the amount of salt, choose protein sources derived from plants such as mushrooms, beans...; Be careful when supplementing calcium: Calcium in food usually does not affect the risk of kidney stones. Therefore, you can still continue to supplement calcium-rich foods, except in cases where your doctor recommends not to. Because when the body lacks calcium, it can easily lead to diseases related to bones and joints.

Call hotline 0287 102 6789 (HCMC) or 024 3872 3872 (Hanoi) to register for a private medical appointment with a specialist, through customer service staff.; Register for a medical appointment with any doctor you trust at the link: https://tamanhhospital.vn/danh-cho-khach-hang/dat-lich-kham/; Send a message on Tam Anh General Hospital Fanpage or Tam Anh General Hospital Urology and Andrology Fanpage; Text message via Zalo OA of Tam Anh General Hospital.
Ureteral stones have the potential to cause serious complications if not treated early and properly. In some cases, if treatment is delayed, the patient's life may be threatened. Therefore, when there are signs of abnormalities in the urinary system, you should quickly go to the hospital to be examined, diagnosed and given appropriate treatment by doctors to help control the condition well.
